element.name: TAlign
element.short: Alignment options for a control, within its Parent control.

descr.p: A control can be aligned as:
At most one control can have alClient alignment.
The order of multiple controls of the same (stackable) alignment is determined by their Left or Top coordinate.
The precedence of conflicting alignment requests (e.g. one at top, one at right) is resolved [how???]
[which provisions exist for alCustom implementation?]

element.short: Control has fixed size and position

element.name: TAlign.alTop
element.short: Control stacked at top, full width.

element.name: TAlign.alBottom

element.name: TAlign.alLeft
element.short: Control stacked at left, full height.

element.name: TAlign.alRight
element.short: Control stacked at right, full height.

element.name: TAlign.alClient
element.short: Control fills remaining client area.

element.name: TAlign.alCustom
element.short: Control has special alignment.
element.descr: [aligned how?]

element.short: Set of alignment options.

element.name: TDragImageList
element.short: TDragImageList - a list of Images to be dragged

descr.p: A drag image is shown when a DragImageList is supplied at all, and when no accepting target is under the mouse, or the source control style includes csDisplayDragImage, or AlwaysShowDragImage is set in the DragObject.
In drag-dock operations typically no drag image is shown, since the DockRect frame already gives all required visual feedback.
descr.pre:
This is a vague idea of the usage of this class:
SetDragImage selects an image from the list, and defines the hotspot within this image.
DragLock specifies a window (handle), to which the image should be attached [what exactly does this mean?]
ShowDragImage shows the image, combined with the mouse cursor. The HotSpot indicates the shift of the image, relative to the current mouse position.
HideDragImage hides the image, shown at its last position.

element.short: Initialize the list of images for dragging

element.name: TDragImageList.BeginDrag
element.short: BeginDrag - start the drag process; returns True if successful

element.name: TDragImageList.DragLock
element.short: DragLock - returns True if dragging has been locked for the specifies window at given location

element.name: TDragImageList.DragMove
element.short: DragMove - move dragged images to specified location and return True if successful

element.name: TDragImageList.DragUnlock
element.short: DragUnlock - unlock the list of images for dragging

element.name: TDragImageList.EndDrag
element.short: EndDrag - retuns True if the drag process has ended

element.name: TDragImageList.HideDragImage
element.short: HideDragImage - method for making dragged image invisible

element.name: TDragImageList.SetDragImage
element.short: Determines the image to be shown

element.name: TDragImageList.ShowDragImage

element.name: TDragImageList.DragHotspot

element.name: TDragImageList.Dragging

element.name: TDragMessage
element.short: DragManager message types.

descr.p: All messages are sent to the target control, except dmDragDrop and dmDragCancel is sent to the source control.
descr.pre: dmDragEnter: mouse enters control dmDragLeave: mouse leaves control dmDragMove: mouse moves over control (after dmDragEnter) dmDragDrop: control dropped dmDragCancel: dragging aborted dmFindTarget: find child control under the mouse

element.short: mouse enters control

element.name: TDragMessage.dmDragLeave
element.short: mouse leaves control

element.name: TDragMessage.dmDragMove
element.short: mouse moves over control (after dmDragEnter)

element.name: TDragMessage.dmDragDrop
element.short: control dropped

element.name: TDragMessage.dmDragCancel
element.short: dragging aborted

element.name: TDragMessage.dmFindTarget
element.short: find possible target control under the mouse

element.name: TDragOverEvent
element.short: The type of an OnDragOver handler.

descr.p: An OnDragOver event is sent by a control, when an object is dragged over it. The handler can specify whether a drop will be accepted or rejected.
descr.remark: Source is polymorphic, can be either the DragObject or the dragged control! This depends on DragObject.AutoCreated, for no sane reason :-(

element.name: TDragOverEvent.Sender
element.short: The possible drop target (control).

element.name: TDragOverEvent.Source
element.short: The object (TDragObject or TControl) being dragged.

element.name: TDragOverEvent.X
element.short: X coordinate of the mouse on screen.

element.name: TDragOverEvent.Y
element.short: Y coordinate of the mouse on screen.

element.name: TDragOverEvent.State
element.short: The current DragState (entering, leaving or moving over the target).

element.name: TDragOverEvent.Accept
element.short: Set Accept to False to reject an drop (default is True).

element.name: TDragDropEvent
element.short: The type of an OnDragDrop (notification) handler.
element.descr: An OnDragDrop event is sent by the drop target (control) on the drop of a dragged object.

element.name: TStartDragEvent
element.short: The type of an OnStartDrag handler.
element.descr: An OnStartDrag event is sent by a control when it shall be dragged and its DragKind is dkDrag. The handler can provide a specific DragDrop object, else a standard TDragDropObjectEx is automatically created by the DragManager.

element.name: TStartDragEvent.Sender
element.short: The control to be dragged.

element.name: TStartDragEvent.DragObject
element.short: Supply your own DragObject, or leave it Nil for automatic creation.

element.name: TEndDragEvent
element.short: The type of an OnEndDrag handler.

descr.p: An OnEndDrag event is sent by a dragged control, when dragging is finished. This happens regardless of whether the operation was drag-drop or drag-dock, and whether the operation ended with a drop or was cancel'd.
Check Target=Nil to distinguish between a drop and a cancel'd operation (Nil).

element.name: TEndDragEvent.Sender
element.short: The dragged control.

element.name: TEndDragEvent.Target
element.short: The drop target (control), or Nil if cancel'd.

element.name: PDragRec
element.short: [dropped!] A pointer to TDragRec drag message parameter record.

element.name: TDragRec
element.short: [dropped!] Drag message parameters.

element.name: TDragObject
element.short: Base class for managing drag operations and user feedback.

descr.p: Every dragging operation has an associated DragObject, holding references to the source and target controls, and other parameters for the customization of the visual user feedback.

A default DragObject is created automatically when a dragging operation starts, and is destroyed when the operation has ended, so that you must not take special care on it. But an application can provide a customized DragObject in the or handlers of the source control (being dragged).
descr.remark: AutoCreated DragObjects imply different behaviour in the DragOver and DragDrop events, where the Source becomes the dragged control, while else the DragObject itself is passed as Source.
descr.p: TDragObject is the ancestor of an whole tree of dragging objects, with the main branches supporting either drag-drop or drag-dock operations. The type of the operation is determined from the property of the source control.
descr.remark: In contrast to the Delphi implementation, Lazarus has moved a couple of methods into the drag performers, so that these are no more available for customization.
descr.p: A Lazarus DragObject mainly supplies the cursor and images, used in visual user feedback. Drag-drop operations typically signal acceptance of an possible drop by variations of the mouse cursor, and optionally can attach to it shapes of the dragged object(s). Drag-dock operations instead show a docking rectangle, that snaps to possible target locations when the mouse moves over docksites.
[entire review DoDi 2011-09-10]

element.name: TDockOrientation
element.short: Orientation of DockZones and docked controls, similar to .

descr.p:
This is a Delphi relict, bound to TDockTree and not very useful in application code.
All DockZones in an DockTree have a unique orientation, horizontal or vertical, indicating how controls are arranged in this zone. When a control is docked into a zone, it obtains the orientation of that zone.
descr.remark: The control's orientation can be stored as the opposite of the zone, depending on the used DockManager.

element.name: TDockOrientation.doNoOrient
element.short: no orientation applies (like alNone)

element.name: TDockOrientation.doHorizontal
element.short: siblings are arranged horizontally, children top-to-bottom

element.name: TDockOrientation.doVertical
element.short: siblings are arranged vertically, children left-to-right

element.name: TDockOrientation.doPages
element.short: children are pages in a tabbed control

element.name: TDockDropEvent
element.short: The type of an OnDockDrop handler.
element.descr: An OnDockDrop event is sent by the drop target (dock site) on the drop of a dragged object.

element.name: TDockDropEvent.Sender
element.short: The drop target (docksite control).

element.name: TDockDropEvent.Source
element.short: The DragDock object, containing information about the dragged object.

element.name: TDockOverEvent
element.short: The type of an OnDockOver handler.
element.descr: An OnDockOver event is sent by a dock site, when an object is dragged over it. The handler can specify whether a drop will be accepted or rejected.

element.name: TDockOverEvent.Sender
element.short: The possible drop target.

element.name: TUnDockEvent
element.short: The type of an OnUnDock handler.
element.descr: An UnDock event is sent by a dock site, before a control is undocked from it. The handler can reject undocking, by setting Allow to False.

element.name: TUnDockEvent.Sender
element.short: The docksite from which the object is undocked.

element.name: TUnDockEvent.Client
element.short: The control to be undocked.

element.name: TUnDockEvent.NewTarget
element.short: The new docksite for Client, Nil when undocked into floating state.

element.name: TUnDockEvent.Allow
element.short: Set Allow to False to reject undocking.

element.name: TStartDockEvent
element.short: The type of an OnStartDock handler.
element.descr: An OnStartDock event is sent by a control when it shall be dragged and its DragKind is dkDock. The handler can provide a specific DragDock object, else a standard TDragDockObjectEx is automatically created by the DragManager.

element.name: TStartDockEvent.DragObject

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent
element.short: An OnGetSiteInfo handler returns information about a docksite.
element.descr: An OnGetSiteInfo event is sent by the DragManager to the nearest docksite. The handler can adjust the snapping rectangle (InfluenceRect), and can reject an drop.

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent.Sender
element.short: The dock site near the mouse pointer.

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent.DockClient

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent.InfluenceRect

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent.MousePos
element.short: The current position of the mouse.

element.name: TGetSiteInfoEvent.CanDock
element.short: Set CanDock to False to reject docking.

element.name: TDragDockObject
element.short: A drag object for drag-dock.

descr.p: This object type serves two main purposes: it allows to distinguish between drag-drop and drag-dock operations, and it implements docking specific information and behaviour.
The primary use is for tree docking, as assumed in the TControl and TWinControl methods.
[entire review DoDi 2011-09-10]

element.name: TDragDockObject.FBrush
element.short: [dropped!]

element.name: TDragDockObject.SetBrush
element.short: [Delphi compatible - dropped!]

element.name: TDragDockObject.DockOffset
element.short: The hotspot offset of the dragged DockRect.

element.name: TDragDockObject.AdjustDockRect
element.short: Adjust the DockRect relative to the dragging hotspot (DockOffset).

descr.remark: The parameter type is bad, should be var. Ignore it please.
descr.p: The default implementation adjusts the stored FDockRect, by DockOffset. This adjustment will make the DockRect appear right over the control, when dragging starts, regardless of where the user clicked onto the control.
You'll rarely have to override this method, since the DockRect is adjusted by every target site's DockManager later.

element.name: TDragDockObject.AdjustDockRect.ARect
element.short: useless, ignore!

element.descr: Invokes Control.DoEndDock.

element.name: TDragDockObject.EraseDragDockImage
element.short: [Delphi compatible - dropped!]

element.name: TDragDockObject.MoveDockImage
element.short: Moves an already visible DockRect.

descr.p: Checks the DockRect for changes against EraseDockRect, to prevent flicker.
Remembers the drawn frame coordinates in EraseDockRect.

element.name: TDragDockObject.InitDock
element.short: Initializes the dragging coordinates.

descr.p: Determines the hotspot offset for adjusting the floating DockRect.
Since the undocked extent of the control doesn't change while dragging, we fix the hotspot offset here.
Usage: OffsetRect(DockRect, FDockOffset);

element.name: TDragDockObject.ShowDockImage
element.short: Shows the DockRect, remembers the coordinates in EraseDockRect

element.name: TDragDockObject.HideDockImage
element.short: Hides the DockRect, invalidates EraseDockRect to prevent further erases.

element.short: [Delphi compatible - dropped!]

element.name: TDragDockObject.Brush
element.short: [Delphi compatible - dropped!]

element.name: TDragDockObject.DockRect
element.short: Screen coordinates of a possible drop location.
element.descr: The DockRect gives feedback to the user, where the dragged control may be dropped. When no docksite signals acceptance, the DockRect reflects the floating state of the dragged control. When a drop will dock the control, the DockRect signifies the approximate position of the docked control.

element.name: TDragDockObject.DropAlign
element.short: How the dragged control will be docked, relative to the target control.
element.descr: When the target is a DockTree, DropAlign indicates the placement of the control relative to DropOnControl. Other docking methods require a specialized (derived) DragDockObject.

element.name: TDragDockObject.DropOnControl
element.short: The already docked control, relative to which the dragged control will be docked. Nil for an empty docksite.

element.name: TDragDockObject.Floating

element.descr: True when the dragged control becomes or stays floating.

element.name: TDockManager
element.short: The layout manager for a docksite.
element.descr: Every docksite can have an DockManager, which handles dropping and arranges the docked controls.

element.short: Handles the messages sent to a docksite.

descr.p: This handler must handle all mouse messages, related to the client area of the docksite that is not covered by docked controls (dock headers...).
Handling mouse messages while dragging is not required. Painting of the docksite has to be implemented in PaintSite.

descr.p: This is a Lazarus specific extension of the Delphi TDockManager. It allows multiple docksites to share the same DockManager instance.

element.name: TDockManager.AutoFreeByControl.Result
element.short: True if the DockManager should be destroyed together with the docksite.

descr.p: ADockObject contains valid DragTarget, DragPos and DragTargetPos relative dock site. DockRect is undetermined.
DropOnControl may be Nil if nothing has been docked yet, or no target control exists at the mouse coordinates.
Returns True if ADockObject.DropAlign has been determined. If False, the DropAlign has to be determined by default procedures.

element.name: TDockManager.GetDockEdge.ADockObject
element.short: The DragDockObject holding all information about the drag-dock operation.

element.name: TDockManager.GetDockEdge.Result
element.short: True if the DropAlign was determined.

element.name: TDockManager.InsertControl
element.short: Position DropCtl relative Control, using the alignment specified by InsertAt.

descr.p: InsertControl determines the placement of the just docked control, forcing a repaint of the container control if necessary.
descr.remark: When SetReplacingControl has been called with a non-Nil Control before, the dropped control only should replace that control.
descr.p: An overloaded version passes the DragDockObject to the dockmanager, allowing to pass more information about the drop. It allows to implement other than tree-style docksites.

element.short: Restores the layout of the docksite from Stream.
element.descr: The controls to be docked can be retrieved by ReloadDockedControl from the docksite; this method returns only existing controls of the given name, owned by the owner of the docksite, by default.

element.name: TDockManager.LoadFromStream.Stream
element.short: The stream with the layout information.

element.name: TDockManager.PaintSite
element.short: Handles special painting of the docksite.
element.descr: While the docked controls paint themselves, eventual dockheaders and other decoration have to be painted by the DockManager.

element.name: TDockManager.PaintSite.DC
element.short: The device context, used to paint.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect
element.short: Determines the DockRect while dragging a control over the docksite.

descr.p: This method updates DockRect for the visual feedback, when a control is dragged over the docksite.
The initial DragDockObject.DockRect spans the entire DockSite.
The Delphi compatible version only can use the parameters determined by the default processing in the docksite.

The Lazarus specific version can update the DockObject with better suited parameters. A DockManager here can implement any algorithm for the placement of a dropped control. The default implementation calls the Delphi compatible version.
When you override the Lazarus version, you may have to determine the dock sibling and DropAlign again, when the default determination (in TControl and TWinControl) is inappropriate.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect.Client
element.short: The dropped control.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect.DropCtl
element.short: The control relative to which Client shall be docked. Nil for docking into the docksite.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect.DropAlign
element.short: How to dock, relative to DropCtl.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect.DockRect
element.short: The screen rectangle of the docksite, to be adjusted by this method.

element.name: TDockManager.PositionDockRect.ADockObject
element.short: The DragDockObject holding all information about the drag-dock operation.

element.name: TDockManager.RemoveControl
element.short: Removes the undocked control from the docksite layout.
element.descr: When SetReplacingControl has been called with a non-Nil argument before, the layout of the docksite should not be changed. Instead the next inserted control should take the place and role of this control.

element.name: TDockManager.RemoveControl.Control
element.short: Control to remove.

element.name: TDockManager.ResetBounds
element.short: ResetBounds refreshes the layout of the docksite

descr.p: This method typically notifies the DockManager of a Resize of the docksite.
When the extent of the docksite really has changed, the DockManager should reposition and resize all docked controls accordingly.
The layout always should be refreshed when Force is True. This is required when e.g. the visibility of docked controls has changed, but not the size of the docksite.

element.name: TDockManager.ResetBounds.Force
element.short: When True, always update the layout.

element.name: TDockManager.SaveToStream
element.short: Saves the docksite layout to Stream.

element.name: TDockManager.SaveToStream.Stream
element.short: Write the layout information into this stream.

element.name: TDockManager.SetReplacingControl
element.short: Specifies the control to be replaced subsequently.

descr.p: This method is called by ReplaceDockedControl, to announce a pending replacement of Control by another control. The next RemoveControl should be ignored, and InsertControl should only exchange the controls, without reorganizing the layout of the docksite. When Control is Nil, this call signals the end of the exchange [obsolete].
descr.remark: The name "SetReplacingControl" is a misnomer, it should read "SetControlToBeReplaced".
descr.p: The intended purpose of this method is the replacement of a docked control by a Notebook, preserving the DockZone. This operation should be handled by an DockManager internally, and calls to this method should be ignored.

element.name: TDockManager.SetReplacingControl.Control
element.short: The control to be replaced later.

element.name: TControlBorderSpacingDefault
element.short: Defines the default values for TControlBorderSpacing.

element.name: TControlBorderSpacing
element.short: TControlBorderSpacing - the spacing around a Control

descr.code:
{ TControlBorderSpacing defines the spacing around a control.
The spacing around its children and between its children is defined in TWinControl.ChildSizing.
Left, Top, Right, Bottom: integer; minimum space left to the autosized control. For example: Control A lies left of control B. A has borderspacing Right=10 and B has borderspacing Left=5. Then A and B will have a minimum space of 10 between.
Around: integer; same as Left, Top, Right and Bottom all at once. This will be added to the effective Left, Top, Right and Bottom. Example: Left=3 and Around=5 results in a minimum spacing to the left of 8.
InnerBorder: integer; This is added to the preferred size. For example: A buttons widget returns 75x25 on GetPreferredSize. CalculatePreferredSize adds 2 times the InnerBorder to the width and height.
CellAlignHorizontal, CellAlignVertical: TControlCellAlign; Used for example when the Parents.ChildSizing.Layout defines a table layout.
}

element.name: TAnchorSide
element.short: TAnchorSide - the side on which anchoring is to be performed for the current control

descr.pre:
TAnchorSide
Class holding the reference sides of the anchors of a TControl. Every TControl has four AnchorSides: AnchorSide[akLeft], AnchorSide[akRight], AnchorSide[akTop] and AnchorSide[akBottom]. Normally if Anchors contain akLeft, and the Parent is resized, the LCL tries to keep the distance between the left side of the control and the right side of its parent client area. With AnchorSide[akLeft] you can define a different reference side. The kept distance is defined by the BorderSpacing.
Example1: +-----+ +-----+ | B | | C | | | +-----+ +-----+
If you want to have the top of B the same as the top of C use B.AnchorSide[akTop].Side:=asrTop; B.AnchorSide[akTop].Control:=C; If you want to keep a distance of 10 pixels between B and C use B.BorderSpacing.Right:=10; B.AnchorSide[akRight].Side:=asrLeft; B.AnchorSide[akRight].Control:=C;
Do not setup in both directions, because this will create a circle, and circles are not allowed.
Example2: +-------+ +---+ | | | A | | B | +---+ | | +-------+
Centering A relative to B: A.AnchorSide[akTop].Side:=arsCenter; A.AnchorSide[akTop].Control:=B; Or use this. It's equivalent: A.AnchorSide[akBottom].Side:=arsCenter; A.AnchorSide[akBottom].Control:=B;

element.name: TAnchorSide.GetSidePosition
element.short: GetSidePosition - returns the position of the side used for anchoring[?]

element.name: TAnchorSide.Owner
element.short: Owner - the Control that owns this AnchorSide
element.descr: TAnchorSide.Owner is the control *to be* anchored. Every control has four AnchorSides. For example AButton1.AnchorSide[akBottom].Owner = AButton1.

element.name: TAnchorSide.Kind
element.short: The Kind is the control side
element.descr: Every control has four AnchorSide, one for each side. For example AButton1.AnchorSide[akLeft].Kind=akLeft.

element.name: TAnchorSide.Control
element.short: The target control of the anchor
element.descr: For example if the right side of a Button1 is anchored to the left side of Edit1, then Button1.AnchorSide[akRight].Control=Edit1 and Button1.AnchorSide[akRight].Side=asrLeft.

element.name: TAnchorSide.Side
element.short: The side on which anchoring is to be performed
element.descr: For example if the right side of a Button1 is anchored to the left side of Edit1, then Button1.AnchorSide[akRight].Control=Edit1 and Button1.AnchorSide[akRight].Side=asrLeft.

element.name: TControl.DoAutoSize
element.short: DoAutoSize - method for actually performing the AutoSize

descr.p: IMPORTANT: Many Delphi controls override this method and many call this method directly after setting some properties.
During handle creation not all interfaces can create complete Device Contexts which are needed to calculate things like text size.
That's why you should always call AdjustSize instead of DoAutoSize.

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeCanStart
element.short: AutoSizeCanStart - checks whether DoAutoSize is permitted to start

descr.pre:
Returns true if DoAutoSize can start. That means, it tests the minimum requirements to start. Some controls need even more.
It returns false if - AutoSize=false - or the control is currently autosizing - or the control is in design state (csDesigning) and is not a top level control (form, frame) - or the control is not visible - or the control is destroying

element.name: TControl.CalculatePreferredSize
element.short: CalculatePreferredSize - returns the preferred height and width.

descr.p: Calculates the preferred width and height for a control, which is used by the LCL autosizing algorithms as default size. Negative or 0 are treated as undefined and the LCL uses other sizes instead.
TWinControl overrides this and asks the interface for theme dependent values. See TWinControl.CalculatePreferredSize for more information.
WithThemeSpace: If true, adds space for stacking.
For example: TRadioButton has a minimum size. But for stacking multiple TRadioButtons there should be some space around. This space is theme dependent, so the parameter is passed to the widgetset.

element.name: TControl.ChangeBounds
element.short: Sets the bounds (left, top, height, width) optionally the BaseBounds of the control.
element.descr: ChangeBounds is called whenever the position or size of the control is set, either via the properties or by the layouter of the LCL. SetBounds calls internally ChangeBounds with KeepBase=false, while the LCL layouter calls it with KeepBase=true. Override this for code that might change the preferred size or resizes other controls. Keep in mind that the given aLeft, aTop, aWidth, aHeight might not be valid and will be changed by the LCL before applied. You can call this function in your custom controls.

element.name: TControl.DoSetBounds
element.short: Perform the actual setting of the boundary rectangle.
element.descr: DoSetBounds is a low level function to set the private variables FLeft, FTop, FWidth, FHeight. Do not call this function, only the LCL calls it. It also updates FClientWidth and FClientHeight accordingly. Override this to update the content layout of the control, for example scroll bars. As always: do not paint here, but call Invalidate and paint in OnPaint or override Paint.

element.name: TControl.ChangeScale
element.short: Change the scale factor (multiplier and divider) for drawing the control.

element.name: TControl.ScaleConstraints
element.short: Scale the minimum and maximum Width and Height.

Visual size of the client area.

element.short: Get the visible part of the logical client area.

descr.p: Includes the ScrollOffset in a TScrollingWinControl Parent.

TControl: When the Parent is a TScrollingWinControl, the ClientRect is offset by it's ScrollOffset. This Rect can be intersected with the visible ClientArea of the Parent, to get the really visible part of the control.
TWinControl: The visible ClientRect is offset by ScrollOffset, to reflect the visible part of the logical ClientRect.

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect
element.short: Get the visible part of a possibly scrolled client area.
element.descr: If Scrolled is False, the ScrollOffset is ignored, so that the ClientRect is returned.

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect.Result
element.short: The visible part of the client area.

element.name: TControl.GetChildsRect.Scrolled
element.short: True forces scrolling taken into account.

element.name: TControl.GetClientScrollOffset
element.short: Returns the offset of the scrolled client area (in a scrolling TWinControl).

element.name: TControl.GetControlOrigin
element.short: Returns the origin (top left pixel) of the control in screen coordinates.

element.name: TControl.WMLButtonDown
element.short: Message handler for left mouse button going down.

element.name: TControl.WMRButtonDown
element.short: Message handler for right mouse button going down.

element.name: TControl.WMMButtonDown
element.short: Message handler for middle mouse button going down.

element.name: TControl.WMLButtonDBLCLK
element.short: Message handler for left mouse button double click.

element.name: TControl.WMRButtonDBLCLK
element.short: Message handler for right mouse button double click.

element.name: TControl.WMMButtonDBLCLK
element.short: Message handler for middle mouse button double click.

element.name: TControl.WMLButtonTripleCLK
element.short: Message handler for left mouse button triple click.

element.name: TControl.WMRButtonTripleCLK
element.short: Message handler for right mouse button triple click.

element.name: TControl.WMMButtonTripleCLK
element.short: Message handler for middle mouse button triple click.

element.name: TControl.WMLButtonQuadCLK
element.short: Message handler for left mouse button quadruple click.

element.name: TControl.WMRButtonQuadCLK
element.short: Message handler for right mouse button quadruple click.

element.name: TControl.WMMButtonQuadCLK
element.short: Message handler for middle mouse button quadruple click.

element.name: TControl.WMXButtonDown
element.short: Message handler for extra mouse button going down.

element.name: TControl.WMXButtonDBLCLK
element.short: Message handler for extra mouse button double click.

element.name: TControl.WMXButtonTripleCLK
element.short: Message handler for extra mouse button triple click.

element.name: TControl.WMXButtonQuadCLK
element.short: Message handler for extra mouse button quadruple click.

element.name: TControl.WMXButtonUp
element.short: Message handler for extra mouse button going up.

element.name: TControl.WMMouseMove
element.short: Message handler for mouse moved.

element.name: TControl.WMLButtonUp
element.short: Message handler for left mouse button going up.

element.name: TControl.WMRButtonUp
element.short: Message handler for right mouse button going up.

element.name: TControl.WMMButtonUp
element.short: Message handler for middle mouse button going up.

element.name: TControl.OnMouseWheel
element.short: OnMouseWheel - event handler for a movement of the mouse wheel

element.name: TControl.OnMouseWheelDown
element.short: OnMouseWheelDown - event handler for downward movement of mouse wheel

element.name: TControl.OnMouseWheelUp
element.short: OnMouseWheelUp - event handler for upward movement of mouse wheel

element.name: TControl.WMMouseWheel
element.short: Protected message to system - when mouse wheel moves

element.name: TControl.DoMouseWheel
element.short: DoMouseWheel - performs the action to deal with a movement of the mouse wheel; returns True if handled

element.name: TControl.DoMouseWheelDown
element.short: DoMouseWheelDown - performs the action for a downward movement[button down?] of the mouse wheel; returns True if handled

element.name: TControl.DoMouseWheelUp
element.short: DoMouseWheelUp - performs the action for an upward movement[?] of the mouse wheel; returns True if handled

element.name: TControl.WMDragStart
element.short: Message handler for [?]

element.name: TControl.WMMove
element.short: Message handler for control moved.

element.name: TControl.WMSize
element.short: Message handler for changed control size.

element.name: TControl.WMWindowPosChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed control position.

element.name: TControl.LMCaptureChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed capture.

element.name: TControl.CMCursorChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed cursor[?].

element.name: TControl.CMEnabledChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed Enabled state.

element.name: TControl.CMHitTest
element.short: Message handler for hit test.

element.name: TControl.CMMouseEnter
element.short: Message handler for mouse enters the control.

element.name: TControl.CMMouseLeave
element.short: Message handler for mouse leaving the control.

element.name: TControl.CMHintShow
element.short: Message handler for hint display.

element.name: TControl.CMSysFontChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed system Font.

element.name: TControl.CMParentFontChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed parent Font.

element.name: TControl.CMParentColorChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed Color.

element.name: TControl.CMParentShowHintChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed ShowHint.

element.name: TControl.CMParentShowHintChanged.Message
element.short: Message handler for changed ShowHint.

element.name: TControl.CMVisibleChanged
element.short: Message handler for changed visibility.

element.name: TControl.CalculateDockSizes
element.short: Saves the docked and undocked extent of the control.

descr.p: In floating state sets UndockWidth/Height to the current Width/Height.
In docked state sets LRDockWidth/TBDockHeight to the current Width/Height.
descr.remark: [Note: should save both in any case, independent from DockOrientation or host Align. Rationale: a DockManager will either ignore these values, or use them according to the *new* alignment. Without a DockManager both extents are required, because no (valid) alignment information applies.]

element.name: TControl.CreateFloatingDockSite
element.short: Create a floating dock site within the Bounds specified as an argument

element.name: TControl.GetDockEdge
element.short: Find out which edge is used for docking (returned in Result)

element.name: TControl.GetFloating
element.short: Guess whether the control is floating.
element.descr: Floating state is assumed when the control has a HostDockSite of FloatingDockSiteClass, and is the only docked client.

element.name: TControl.GetFloatingDockSiteClass
element.short: Returns the class for a floating host dock site

element.name: TControl.BeginAutoDrag
element.short: Start the AutoDrag process.

element.name: TControl.DockTrackNoTarget
element.short: Adjust the DockRect for floating state (not over a DockSite)

element.name: TControl.DoDock
element.short: Adjust the control's position and extent for the new docksite.

descr.p: If NewDockSite=Nil, Parent is set to Nil (in preparation of floating the control).

Otherwise ARect is adjusted to fit into the logical ClientRect of the NewDockSite. The origin is adjusted according to Align[??? should be DropAlign!], so that the control sits at the according side of the NewDockSite.
Finally the computed coordinates are stored, in BoundsRectForNewParent when the NewDockSite differs from Parent, else in BoundsRect.
ARect is the perfect BoundsRect for the control, in screen coordinates when it becomes floating, or in client coordinates of the target docksite.

element.name: TControl.DoDragMsg
element.short: Handler for a drag message, sent by the DragManager

ul.li: On dmFindTarget: return Self for the DropOnControl.
On dmDragEnter/Leave/Move: invokes DragOver or, if docking, the target.DockOver. Result indicates acceptance of an drop.
On dmDragDrop: invokes DragDrop or, if docking, the target.DockDrop.

descr.p: Sender is the DragDockObject when docking. Else if the DragObject has been AutoCreated, the dragged control is passed to DragOver as the Sender; otherwise the DragObject itself is passed as Sender.

element.name: TControl.DoEndDock
element.short: Invokes the OnEndDock handler

element.name: TControl.DoEndDrag
element.short: Invokes the OnEndDrag handler

element.name: TControl.DoStartDock
element.short: Invokes the OnStartDock handler

element.name: TControl.DoStartDrag
element.short: Invokes the OnStartDrag handler

element.name: TControl.DragCanceled
element.short: DragCanceled - handler for a canceld drag.

element.name: TControl.DragOver
element.short: Determines whether a drop is acceptable, using the OnDragOver handler.

descr.p: An OnDragOver handler is required, or any drop will be rejected (Accept becomes False).
When an OnDragOver handler is installed, Accept is set to True and can be changed by the handler.
descr.remark: Caution: Sender can be either a TDragObject, or the dragged control.

element.name: TControl.PositionDockRect
element.short: Get the DockRect for an drop.
element.descr: Either calls the DockManager.PositionDockRect of the target site, or DragDockObject.AdjustDockRect after moving the undocked control rectangle to the DragPos. AdjustDockRect takes the hotspot of the DockRect into account.

element.name: TControl.SetDragMode
element.short: SetDragMode - specify the mode for dragging

element.name: TControl.Click
element.short: Invokes the OnClick handler.

element.name: TControl.DblClick
element.short: Invokes the OnDblClick handler.

element.name: TControl.TripleClick
element.short: Invokes the OnTripleClick handler.

element.name: TControl.QuadClick
element.short: Invokes the OnQuadClick handler.

element.name: TControl.MouseDown
element.short: Handler for MouseDown events.

descr.p: Called by the MouseDown message handler. Handles Focus changes. Notifies the DragManager while dragging [for what purpose???]. Finally calls the handler.
X, Y is the mouse position in client coordinates.

element.name: TControl.MouseDown.Button
element.short: which buttons are down

element.name: TControl.MouseDown.Shift
element.short: which of Ctrl, Shift or Alt keys are also pressed

element.name: TControl.MouseMove
element.short: Handler for MouseMove events.

descr.p: Called by the MouseMove message handler. The DragManager is notified while the control is being dragged. Finally the OnMouseMove handler is invoked.
X, Y is the mouse position in client coordinates.

element.name: TControl.MouseMove.Shift
element.short: The currently pressed mouse buttons and modifier keys.

element.name: TControl.MouseUp
element.short: MouseUp invokes the OnMouseUp handler.

element.name: TControl.MouseEnter
element.short: MouseEnter invokes the OnMouseEnter handler.

element.name: TControl.MouseLeave
element.short: MouseLeave invokes the OnMouseLeave handler.

element.name: TControl.DialogChar
element.short: DialogChar - checks whether Message is a dialog message.[?]

element.name: TControl.Changed
element.short: Changed - method to signal that a change has occured

element.name: TControl.GetPalette
element.short: GetPalette - returns a handle to the palette for this control

element.name: TControl.ChildClassAllowed
element.short: ChildClassAllowed - returns True if the specified class is allowed to be a child of this class

element.name: TControl.DefineProperties
element.short: Defines which non-published properties should be streamed (none here).

descr.p: Implements the assignment to an Action object, otherwise calls the inherited method.
The copied properties are:

element.name: TControl.InvalidateControl
element.short: Request a repaint of the control.

element.name: TControl.InvalidateControl
element.short: Request a repaint of the control.

element.name: TControl.FontChanged
element.short: FontChanged - handles an change of the Font property.

element.name: TControl.GetAction
element.short: Returns the Action property.

element.name: TControl.RealGetText
element.short: Returns the Caption property.
element.descr: This method is called by GetText, when GetTextBuf is not overridden.

element.name: TControl.RealGetText.Result
element.short: The Caption property.

element.name: TControl.RealSetText
element.short: Sets the Caption property.
element.descr: This method is called by SetText, when SetTextBuf is not overridden.

element.name: TControl.RealSetText.Value
element.short: The text-string that is to be stored

element.name: TControl.SetAction
element.short: Set up the action to be associated with this control

element.name: TControl.SetColor
element.short: Set up the color to be used by the control

element.name: TControl.SetEnabled
element.short: Set up the flag to determine whether the control is to be enabled

element.name: TControl.SetHint
element.short: Set up the hinting pop-up for this control

element.name: TControl.SetName
element.short: Set the name of the control

element.name: TControl.SetParent
element.short: Sets the Parent property.

element.name: TControl.SetParentComponent
element.short: Sets the Parent property, if NewParentCompnent is a TWinControl

element.name: TControl.WndProc
element.short: The general message handler for this control.
element.descr: Preprocesses several messages, then calls Dispatch to invoke the applicable message handler.

element.name: TControl.WndProc.TheMessage
element.short: The message to handle.

element.name: TControl.ParentFormHandleInitialized
element.short: ParentFormHandleInitialized - called by ChildHandlesCreated of parent form

descr.p: Functions like GetTextWidth require valid widgets and their device contexts. That's why AdjustSize delays AutoSizing till this moment.

element.name: TControl.CaptureChanged
element.short: Handler for mouse capture moved to a different control.
element.descr: Notifies the DragManager of the changed capture control, to stop dragging this control. A very dangerous implementation, that can cause immediate abort of dragging before dragging really starts.

element.name: TControl.Notification
element.short: Notification handler for insertion or deletion of components.

descr.p: First the inherited is invoked, to notify all attached notification handlers.

If Operation is removal, additional actions are performed, depending on AComponent:
PopupMenu, Action, or anchors to the removed control are detached.

element.name: TControl.Notification.AComponent
element.short: The component being inserted or removed.

element.name: TControl.Notification.Operation
element.short: The action (opInsert or opRemove).

element.name: TControl.CanTab
element.short: CanTab - if True, the Tab key can be used to navigate to this control.

element.name: TControl.GetDeviceContext
element.short: Returns a device context handle for the control.
element.descr: Initializes the device context position to the control origin, and shrinks its clipping rectangle to the control bounds.

element.name: TControl.GetDeviceContext.Result
element.short: The device context.

element.name: TControl.GetDeviceContext.WindowHandle
element.short: Returns the window of the device context.

element.name: TControl.GetEnabled
element.short: Returns the Enabled status.

element.name: TControl.GetPopupMenu
element.short: GetPopupMenu - returns the popup menu for this control.

element.name: TControl.DoOnShowHint
element.short: Invokes the OnShowHint event handler.

element.name: TControl.VisibleChanging
element.short: Invokes all OnVisibleChanging handlers.

element.name: TControl.AddHandler
element.short: Adds an notification handler.
element.descr: Notification handlers allow to notify other components of certain events. When the registered event occurs, all installed (added) handlers are invoked.

element.name: TControl.AddHandler.HandlerType
element.short: Type of the event.

element.name: TControl.AddHandler.AMethod
element.short: The handler to be added.

element.name: TControl.AddHandler.AsFirst
element.short: Unused. [If true, the handler is added before all installed handlers?]

element.name: TControl.RemoveHandler
element.short: Removes the given notification handler.

element.name: TControl.RemoveHandler.HandlerType
element.short: Type of the notification.

element.name: TControl.RemoveHandler.AMethod
element.short: The handler to be removed.

element.name: TControl.DoContextPopup
element.short: Invokes the OnContextPopup handler.
element.descr: The handler can show and handle the menu selection itself. If so, it should set Handled to True. [to be moved into OnContextPopup]

element.name: TControl.DoContextPopup.MousePos
element.short: Mouse position, used to place the menu.

element.name: TControl.DoContextPopup.Handled
element.short: To be set by the handler, when it has handled the menu display and selection.

element.name: TControl.GetActionLinkClass
element.short: GetActionLinkClass - returns the default Action class.

element.name: TControl.ActionChange
element.short: Handler for a changed Action.
element.descr: Several properties are copied from the new Action.

element.name: TControl.ActionChange.Sender
element.short: The changed Action.

element.name: TControl.ActionChange.CheckDefaults
element.short: When True, forces update of all properties. Otherwise only properties in default state are overwritten.

element.name: TControl.ActionLink
element.short: Link to the default Action associated with this control.

element.name: TControl.AutoSize
element.short: Whether auto-size is to be used

descr.p: AutoSize permits the size of a control to be adjusted automatically, for example a button can become bigger or smaller to accommodate a longer or shorter caption.
Default is false, ie no auto-sizing

element.name: TControl.Ctl3D
element.short: Ctl3D - retained for Delphi compatibility; even there it is deprecated

element.name: TControl.DragCursor
element.short: DragCursor - the style of cursor to be used during the Drag process
element.descr: Default is crDrag. When no drop is allowed, the cursor changes temporarily to crNoDrop.

element.name: TControl.DragKind
element.short: DragKind - what sort of dragging? Drag or Dock
element.descr: Set to dkDrag to allow for drag-drop, or to dkDock to allow for drag-dock.

element.name: TControl.DragMode
element.short: DragMode - whether manual or automatic

descr.p: Default is dmManual, meaning that dragging must be started in code.

Set to dmAutomatic to allow the user to drag this control. In this mode dragging can start immediately (on left mouse button press) or delayed, after the mouse has been moved away by a number of pixels (Threshold).

element.name: TControl.MouseCapture
element.short: Are mouse messages captured by this control?

descr.p: Mouse messages can be sent to a capturing control. This occurs automatically when a control is dragged. In normal operation all mouse messages are sent to the control under the mouse pointer.

Applications should capture mouse events only for special purposes, and release the capture as soon as a the target position has been determined. Limited user feedback is possible while the mouse is captured, but not all application controls will work properly so long.

element.name: TControl.ParentFont
element.short: ParentFont - should the control use the same font as the parent? Default is true.

element.name: TControl.ParentColor
element.short: ParentColor - should the control have the same color as the parent? Default is true.

element.name: TControl.ParentShowHint
element.short: ParentShowHint - does the control use the same hinting behaviour as its parent? Default is true.

element.name: TControl.SessionProperties
element.short: The stored (saved) properties of the current session, expressed as a string

element.name: TControl.Text
element.short: Text - the character string associated with the control.

descr.p: This is the character string, shown in controls with visible text content (TEdit...).
descr.remark: BEWARE: In other controls it can be the Name or Caption of the control, quite tricky to use.

element.name: TControl.OnConstrainedResize
element.short: Event Handler for constrained resize

descr.p: Event handler needs to be supplied to cover the need to resize a control within the given constraints of maximum and minimum width and height

element.name: TControl.OnContextPopup
element.short: Event handler to supply information when a context-sensitive pop-up menu is required

element.name: TControl.OnDblClick
element.short: Event Handle for mouse double-click

descr.p: Double-clicking is much more common in a Windows environment than in Unix or Linux, where single-clicking is the default method for selecting an object. However, in all environments there could be valid use for a double-click, and a method should be supplied if appropriate.

element.name: TControl.OnTripleClick
element.short: Event handler for mouse triple-click

element.name: TControl.OnQuadClick
element.short: Event handler for quadruple click

element.name: TControl.OnDragDrop
element.short: Event handler for the drop of a control onto this control.

descr.p: The handler determines what shall happen when another control is dropped onto this (Sender) control.
Sender is the target control onto which the Source control is dropped.
X and Y are the client coordinates of the drop.

element.name: TControl.OnDragOver
element.short: Event handler for the case when a control is dragged over another control

element.name: TControl.OnEndDock
element.short: Event handler for the end of a docking operation

descr.p: This message is sent to the dragged control.
Sender is the control to be docked [or DragDock object?].
Target is the control into which the Sender is docked, or Nil when dragging has been aborted.
X and Y are the screen coordinates of the drop.

element.name: TControl.OnEndDrag
element.short: Event handler for the end of a dragging process

descr.p: This message is sent to the dragged control.
Sender is the dragged control [or DragDrop object?].
Target is the control onto which the Sender has been dropped, or Nil when dragging has been aborted.
X and Y are the screen coordinates of the drop.

element.name: TControl.OnMouseDown
element.short: Event handler for when a mouse button is pressed down

element.name: TControl.OnMouseMove
element.short: Event handler for mouse movement within the current control

element.name: TControl.OnMouseUp
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse button is released, ie "up"

element.name: TControl.OnMouseEnter
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse enters the area of the current control

element.name: TControl.OnMouseLeave
element.short: Event handler for when the mouse leaves the area of the current control

element.name: TControl.OnStartDock
element.short: Event handler for the start of a docking operation

descr.p: The handler can provide a special DragDock object, otherwise a default object is created.

element.name: TControl.OnStartDrag
element.short: Event handler for start of dragging operation

descr.p: The handler can provide a special DragControl object, otherwise a default object is created.

element.name: TControl.OnEditingDone
element.short: Event handler when editing is done

element.name: TControl.FCompStyle
element.short: FCompStyle - deprecated

element.name: TControl.DragDrop
element.short: Invokes the OnDragDrop handler, when the control is dropped.

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.Source
element.short: The object to be dragged and dropped

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.X
element.short: The X co-ordinate to which the object is to be dropped (target)

element.name: TControl.DragDrop.Y
element.short: The Y co-ordinate to which the object is to be dropped (target)

element.name: TControl.Dock
element.short: Moves the control into a new docksite.

descr.p: Calls DoDock to calculate the new position the control, when docked into an unmanaged or floating docksite.

element.errors: An exception is raised if there is already a docking process in progress for this control

element.name: TControl.Dock.NewDockSite
element.short: The host control to which which the control is to be docked

element.name: TControl.Dock.ARect
element.short: The position at which the control is to be docked.

element.name: TControl.ManualDock
element.short: Docks a control programmatically.

descr.p: Docks this control into NewDockSite, relative to DropControl. When NewDockSite is Nil, the control becomes floating.

When the new docksite uses an DockManager, and DropControl is not Nil, the control will be docked relative to DropControl, as specified by ControlSide. The interpretation of ControlSide depends on the DockManager of NewDockSite, or on the OnDockDrop handler in an unmanaged docksite. A tree docking manager (TDockTree) should interpret alCustom as NoteBook docking, i.e. a tabbed notebook is created in place of DropControl, and both DropControl and this control are docked into pages of this notebook.

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.Result
element.short: The function returns True if a manual dock has been successfully performed.

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.NewDockSite
element.short: The new site to which the control is docked, if DropControl is nil.

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.DropControl
element.short: If nil (default) then ignored, else used as the control for docking, on side specified by ControlSide

element.name: TControl.ManualDock.ControlSide
element.short: The side of DropControl on which the control is to be docked.

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat
element.short: Undocks the control into floating state.
element.descr: TWinControls float for themselves, for TControls a floating host dock site is created, and the control is docked into it.

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat.Result
element.short: The function returns True if a manual float has been succesfully performed.

element.name: TControl.ManualFloat.TheScreenRect
element.short: The screen area where the floating control is moved.
element.descr:
The rectangle within which the floating control is located
(ie the location of the floating dock site to which the control is docked) [site or client coordinates?]

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl
element.short: Remove a previously docked control and put a new control in its place

descr.p: This method works only when the control to replace resides in a managed docksite (using an DockManager), or is not docked at all. Even then exist situations where it won't work as expected, depending on the used DockManager and other subtle conditions.
When the control to replace is docked, then it's replaced by this control; otherwise this control becomes floating (seems to be a design flaw).
Finally the control to replace is docked into NewDockSite, according to DropControl and ControlSide (see ).
This method primarily exists for use by the DockManager itself, for NoteBook docking. It should not be used in application code.

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.Result
element.short: Returns True if a docked control has been successfully replaced with a new one

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.Control
element.short: The old control that was previously docked at this site

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.NewDockSite
element.short: The new site for docking; used if DropControl is nil

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.DropControl
element.short: The control site to be used for docking, unless it is nil when it is igored. Passed straight through as an argument to ManualDock

element.name: TControl.ReplaceDockedControl.ControlSide
element.short: The side to which the new control is to be aligned; passed straight through as an argument to ManualDock

element.name: TControl.Dragging
element.short: Returns True if the control is being dragged

element.name: TControl.Dragging.Result
element.short: Returns True if the control is being dragged

element.name: TControl.AdjustSize
element.short: AdjustSize - Smart way to DoAutoSize

descr.p: TControl.AdjustSize calls DoAutoSize in a smart fashion.
During loading and handle creation the calls are delayed.

This method initially does the same as TWinControl.DoAutoSize. But since DoAutoSize is commonly overriden by descendant components, it is not useful to perform all tests, which can result in too much overhead.[?] To reduce this the LCL calls AdjustSize instead.

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeDelayed
element.short: Auto-sizing has been delayed until some other process is complete

element.name: TControl.AutoSizeDelayed.Result
element.short: Returns True if auto-sizing has been delayed

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour
element.short: AnchorToNeighbour - anchoring instructions

descr.p: Setup AnchorSide to anchor a side to the side of a neighbour sibling. For example Right side to Left side, or Top side to Bottom.

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Side
element.short: The side on which we should anchor

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Space
element.short: The minimum space to be left around the control when anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorToNeighbour.Sibling
element.short: The sibling control to which we should anchor

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel
element.short: AnchorParallel - instructions for anchoring beside another control

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Side
element.short: The side which we should anchor to the sibling

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Space
element.short: The size of the space to be left around the control when anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorParallel.Sibling
element.short: The sibling control to which we should anchor in a parallel manner

element.name: TControl.AnchorHorizontalCenterTo
element.short: AnchorHorizontal - instructions for anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorHorizontalCenterTo.Sibling
element.short: Another control to which the current control is to be anchored, centred horizontally

element.name: TControl.AnchorVerticalCenterTo
element.short: AnchorVertical - instructions for anchoring

element.name: TControl.AnchorVerticalCenterTo.Sibling
element.short: Another control to which the current control is to be anchored, centered vertically

element.name: TControl.SetBounds
element.short: Sets the bounds (left, top, height, width) of the control.
element.descr: SetBounds can be used to change the left, top, width, height all at once, reducing some overhead. Use DisableAutoSize/EnableAutoSize to reduce recomputing/moving/resizing further. SetBounds is called when the properties Left, Top, Width, Height, BoundsRect is set. SetBounds updates the BaseBounds and BaseParentClientSize, which are used by anchoring to keep the distance. For example loading a Form with TMemo and the lfm contains TMemo's Left and Width, then SetBounds is called two times for the memo. When the user maximizes a window, SetBounds is called for the form, but not for the Memo, keeping the BaseBounds of the Memo. If the Memo is anchored to the right, the Width of the Memo is changed based on the BaseBounds and BaseParentClientSize.[?] Keep in mind that the given aLeft, aTop, aWidth, aHeight might not be valid and will be changed by the LCL before applied. Delphi calls SetBounds more often. SetBounds calls ChangeBounds with KeepBase=false.[format this]

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aLeft
element.short: The X co-ordinate of the top left pixel of the control

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aTop
element.short: The Y co-ordinate of the top left pixel of the control

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aWidth

element.name: TControl.SetBounds.aHeight

element.descr: Checks that this is a new control, then calls SetBounds to set up coordinates defining its position

element.name: TControl.GetPreferredSize
element.short: Returns default/preferred height and width, to be used in autosizing.

descr.p: Called during AutoSize [link?] calculations. Only positive values are valid. Negative or 0 are treated as undefined and the LCL uses other sizes instead.
WithThemeSpace: If true, adds space for stacking. [add to arguments]
For example: TRadioButton has a minimum size. But for stacking multiple TRadioButtons there should be some space around. This space is theme dependent, so the parameter is passed to the widgetset

TWinControl overrides this and asks the interface for theme dependent values. See
TWinControl.CalculatePreferredSize for more information.

element.name: TControl.InvalidatePreferredSize
element.short: Mark the preferred size no longer valid, for this control and all parents (implies that we will look for another).

Defaults set by the Constructor include ControlStyle, Constraints, BorderSpacing, Anchoring, alignment, CaptureMouseBottons, Color, Visibility, Hinting, Cursor, Font, the WindowProcedure to be used, the Help type, the FloatingDockSite and Enabled properties

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf
element.short: Gets text associated with the control from the widget.

descr.remark: See SetTextBuf [document in one place?]
descr.pre: * The VCL implementation relies on the virtual Get/SetTextBuf to * exchange text between widgets and VCL. This means a lot of * (unnecesary) text copies. * The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). * To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is * introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface. The * default Get/SetTextbuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. * As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText * calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying. * To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always * override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for * compatibility.

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.Result
element.short: Pointer to the buffer containing the text

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.Buffer
element.short: Pointer to the buffer containing the string

element.name: TControl.GetTextBuf.BufSize
element.short: Length of the buffer

element.name: TControl.GetTextLen
element.short: Get the length of the specified text

element.name: TControl.SetTextBuf
element.short: Sends text associated with the control to the widget.

descr.p: This method exists only for VCL compatibility. The VCL sends text from the Text or Caption properties immediately to the widget, using WM_SETTEXT. The LCL instead transfers an string to the widget interface, and leaves eventual string/PChar conversions to the interface.
descr.remark: Do not override this method, because this will only cause overhead in the communication between LCL and widgetsets. The LCL SetText method bypasses SetTextBuf, if not overridden, and calls the fast RealSetText method. Instead override RealSetText, if ever required.

This means a lot of * (unnecesary) text copies. * The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). * To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is * introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface. The * default Get/SetTextbuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. * As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText * calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying. * To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always * override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for * compatibility.

element.name: TControl.Caption

descr.p: By default, the Caption is the same as the control Name in the Object Inspector, and the developer needs to set it explicitly to some new text.
descr.remark: [todo: remove Text specific content]
descr.p: The VCL implementation relies on the virtual Get/SetTextBuf to exchange text between widgets and VCL. This means a lot of (unnecesary) text copies.
The LCL uses strings for exchanging text (more efficient). To maintain VCL compatibility, the virtual RealGet/SetText is introduced. These functions interface with the LCLInterface.
The default Get/SetTextBuf implementation calls the RealGet/SetText. As long as the Get/SetTextBuf isn't overridden Get/SetText calls RealGet/SetText to avoid PChar copying.
To keep things optimal, LCL implementations should always override RealGet/SetText. Get/SetTextBuf is only kept for compatibility.

element.name: TControl.OnResize
element.short: Event Handler for resize of control

descr.p: This event is triggered whenever the Width, Height, ClientWidth or ClientHeight of the control has changed. During autosize the size can change multiple times and only the last change triggers the OnResize. Use OnResize to react to resizes or to put your custom aligning, positioning code into this. To also react on moves, use the OnChangeBounds event.

Common mistake: Keep in mind that ClientWidth and ClientHeight can change even when Width, Height stays the same. For example when the theme changes, the Width and Height remain the same, but the changed frame reduces the ClientWidth and ClientHeight. This does not happen that often under Windows, but it happens quite often on other platforms.
Especially it is not sufficient to write only a TForm.OnResize handler to resize all controls on the form. This is a common bug in Delphi applications.[???]

descr.remark: The Visible property does not take into account control's parent visibility. Use IsVisible method to get the real visibility.

element.name: TControlChildSizing
element.short: How Child controls are to be sized relative to parent.

descr.code:
{ LeftRightSpacing, TopBottomSpacing: integer; minimum space between client border and nearest child control. For example: ClientLeftRight=5 means leftmost child's Left position is at least 5.
HorizontalSpacing, VerticalSpacing: integer; minimum space between each child control. }
{ Defines how child controls are resized/aligned.
cesAnchorAligning, cssAnchorAligning Anchors and Align work like Delphi. For example if Anchors property of the control is [akLeft], it means fixed distance between left border of parent's client area. [akRight] means fixed distance between right border of the control and the right border of the parent's client area. When the parent is resized the child is moved to keep the distance. [akLeft,akRight] means fixed distance to left border and fixed distance to right border. When the parent is resized, the controls width is changed (resized) to keep the left and right distance. Same for akTop,akBottom.
Align=alLeft for a control means set Left leftmost, Top topmost and maximize Height. The width is kept, if akRight is not set. If akRight is set in the Anchors property, then the right distance is kept and the control's width is resized. If there several controls with Align=alLeft, they will not overlapp and be put side by side. Same for alRight, alTop, alBottom. (Always expand 3 sides).
Align=alClient. The control will fill the whole remaining space. Setting two children to Align=alClient does only make sense, if you set maximum Constraints.
Order: First all alTop children are resized, then alBottom, then alLeft, then alRight and finally alClient.
cesScaleChilds, cssScaleChilds Scale children, keep space between them fixed. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the children are scaled to fill the space. You can set maximum Constraints. Then the other children are scaled more. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then the children are scaled with Factor 2. If B has a maximum constraint width of 30, then first the children will be scaled with 1.5 (A.Width=15, B.Width=30, C.Width=45). Then A and C (15+45=60 and 30 pixel space left) will be scaled by 1.5 again, to a final result of: A.Width=23, B.Width=30, C.Width=67 (23+30+67=120).
cesHomogenousChildGrowth, cssHomogenousChildDecrease Enlarge children equally. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the remaining space is distributed equally to each child. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then 60/3=20 is added to each Child. If B has a maximum constraint width of 30, then first 10 is added to all children (A.Width=20, B.Width=30, C.Width=40). Then A and C (20+40=60 and 30 pixel space left) will get 30/2=15 additional, resulting in: A.Width=35, B.Width=30, C.Width=55 (35+30+55=120).
cesHomogenousSpaceGrowth Enlarge space between children equally. Children are resized to their normal/advised size. If there is some space left in the client area of the parent, then the space between the children is expanded. For example: 3 child controls A, B, C with A.Width=10, B.Width=20 and C.Width=30 (total=60). If the Parent's client area has a ClientWidth of 120, then there will be 60/2=30 space between A and B and between B and C. }

element.name: TWinControl.DoSetBounds
element.short: DoSetBounds - anticipate the new clientwidth/height and call inherited method

descr.p: Anticipate the new clientwidth/height and call inherited method

Normally the clientwidth/clientheight is adjusted automatically by the interface. But it is up to interface when this will be done. The gtk for example just puts resize requests into a queue. The LCL would resize the child components just after this procedure due to the clientrect. On complex forms with lots of nested controls, this would result in thousands of resizes.
Changing the clientrect in the LCL to the most probable size reduces unneccessary resizes.

element.name: TWinControl.DoAutoSize
element.short: DoAutoSize - performs a lot of calculations and adjustments of child components in the window before automatically adjusting the size of the window itself

ul.li: Checks whether Autosize is in fact permitted
Checks for unaligned child components and fits them in as best it can
Moves the constrained (aligned) child components to the correct position
Adjusts the size of the client rectangle
Adjusts the bounds of the whole control

descr.p: Because this method involves so much overhead, the simpler TControl.AdjustSize is often called instead.

element.name: TWinControl.CalculatePreferredSize
element.short: CalculatePreferredSize returns the default/preferred width and height for a TWinControl, for use by LCL autosizing.

descr.p: Calls the inherited method to calculate the default/preferred width and height for a TWinControl, which is used by the LCL autosizing algorithms as default size. Only positive values are valid. Negative or 0 are treated as undefined and the LCL uses other sizes instead.
TWinControl overrides this:

ul.li: If there are child components, their total preferred size is calculated
If this value can not be computed (e.g. the children depend too much on their parent clientrect), then the interface is asked for the preferred size

descr.p: For example the preferred size of a TButton is the size, where the label fits exactly. This depends heavily on the current theme and widgetset.
This value is independent of constraints and siblings, only the inner parts are relevant.

WithThemeSpace: If true, adds space for stacking. For example: TRadioButton has a minimum size. But for stacking multiple TRadioButtons there should be some space around. This space is theme dependent, so it is passed as a parameter to the widgetset.

element.short: Index of the docked client.

element.name: TWinControl.DockManager
element.short: The docking layout manager for this control.

descr.p: A docksite can be managed (using an DockManager) or unmanaged (positioning docked controls in the event handlers). The DockManager determines the placement of docked controls, by setting DropOnControl and DropAlign before the drop, and by resizing and positioning the control when it's dropped.
A DockManager is used only when UseDockManager also is True. Setting UseDockManager to True creates an DockManager of the DefaultDockManagerClass for this docksite, if none was previously installed.
An unmanaged docksite, without an DockManager, can handle the placement of dropped controls in the OnDockOver and OnDockDrop event handlers.

element.name: TWinControl.DockSite
element.short: Is this a dock site? (read/write, default is False)
element.descr: Enable this to use the DockManager automatically. For example to call DockManager.ResetBounds when the control resizes.

element.name: TWinControl.TabStop

descr.p: Use the TabStop to allow or disallow access to the control using the Tab key.
If the TabStop is True, the control is in the tab order. If TabStop is False, the control is not in the tab order and the user can't press the Tab key to move to the control.

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyDown
element.short: OnKeyDown - event handler for instance when key is down while control has focus

descr.p: OnKeyDown - event handler for instance when key is down while control has focus
Differs from OnKeyPress in that the key may have already been down when the control received focus; with OnKeyPress the key needs to become pressed while the control has focus.

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyPress
element.short: OnKeyPress - event controller for a key being pressed while the control has focus. To properly handle national chars use UTF8KeyPress instead.

descr.p: OnKeyPress - event controller for a key being pressed while the control has focus
Differs from OnKeyDown in that the key needs to become pressed while the control has focus; with OnKeyDown the key may have already been down when the control received focus.

Note: we recommend you to use OnUTF8KeyPress to prevent data lost. National chars are converted from UTF8 to the system encoding in OnKeyPressEvent. This can cause a data lost if symbol cannot be converted, which means OnKeyPress is not called or with Char=#0. OnUTF8KeyPress does not perform this conversion.

element.name: TWinControl.OnKeyUp
element.short: OnKeyUp - event handler for instance when a key is up (not pressed) while the control has focus

descr.p: OnKeyUp - event handler for instance when a key is up (not pressed) while the control has focus
The key may already have been up when the control received focus, or a pressed key may become released during the time the control has focus.

Differs from OnKeyDown in that the char does not converts to the system encoding

element.name: TGraphicControl
element.short: TGraphicControl is the base class for all lightweight controls.

descr.p: TGraphicControl supports simple lightweight controls that do not need the ability to accept keyboard input or contain other controls.
Since lightweight controls do not wrap GUI screen objects, they are faster and use fewer resources than controls based on TWinControl.

TGraphicControl provides a
Canvas property for access to the control's drawing surface and a virtual
Paint method called in response to paint requests received by the parent control.

descr.p: The TGraphicsControl.Canvas is a clipped window in the parent canvas.
If you ask for the Canvas.Width or Canvas.Height, you are actually getting the parent control's Canvas dimensions.
To get the dimensions of the TGraphicControl, you must query the ClientRect.
